target_title: server: fix listening on localhost when IPv6 is not supported

note.body:
I think checking both `ECONNREFUSED|EAFNOSUPPORT` is the practical way to handle this.

If the system supports IPv6 (compile-time) but disables it at run-time (via sysctl or similar) then the error will be `ECONNREFUSED`


- EAFNOSUPPORT: Indicates that the system cannot handle the requested address family (e.g., IPv6 support is entirely absent in the kernel or unavailable).

- ECONNREFUSED: Indicates that a connection or binding attempt was actively refused by the system. One possible cause is that the protocol is administratively disabled.

This happens for example inside a Docker container, as those (by default) don't configure IPv6.

For example: check the output of `ip -6 addr` on your computer vs on any random Docker container that you can run.

In the [WPT test-suite we have been workarounding this issue for a long time](https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/tools/wptrunner/wptrunner/browsers/webkitgtk_minibrowser.py#L34) because the CI system for the tests on https://wpt.fyi (taskcluster) run inside Docker containers (with IPv6 disabled by default) and then the WebKit WebDriver (which depends on libsoup) fails to start completely because it receives a `ECONNREFUSED` when it tries to bind to the IPv6 localhost (`::1`) which is not available there (inside the Docker container) even when the system (the host) supports IPv6 (kernel has support, but it is disabled for that container)

target_title: server: fix listening on localhost when IPv6 is not supported

note.body:
The connection refused error is coming from the call to `g_socket_bind()` in `soup_listener_new_for_address()`. I don't think we can do much about it. Certainly we don't want `soup_listener_new_for_address()` to convert `G_IO_ERROR_CONNECTION_REFUSED` to `G_IO_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED`.

```
EAFNOSUPPORT
      The implementation does not support the specified address family.
```

My interpretation of this error would be something like: C library or the kernel doesn't support IPv6. In this case, IPv6 is supported but is disabled.

target_title: server: fix listening on localhost when IPv6 is not supported

note.body: The documentation for `socket()` explicitly says `EAFNOSUPPORT` is the correct error to handle: https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/socket.2.html

note.body:
# Report 3 and Report 4

- Heap buffer overflow in `soup-content-sniffer.c:sniff_feed_or_html()` 
- Heap buffer overflow in `soup-content-sniffer.c:skip_insignificant_space()`

## Download

```bash
$ git clone https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libsoup.git
```

## Export flags

```bash
$ export CC=clang
$ export CXX=clang++
$ export CFLAGS="-g -O0 -DFUZZING_BUILD_MODE_UNSAFE_FOR_PRODUCTION -fsanitize=address -fsanitize=fuzzer-no-link"
$ export CXXFLAGS="-g -O0 -DFUZZING_BUILD_MODE_UNSAFE_FOR_PRODUCTION -fsanitize=address -fsanitize=fuzzer-no-link"
$ export LIB_FUZZING_ENGINE="-fsanitize=fuzzer"
```

## Compile

### Patch before compile

```patch
diff --git a/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.c b/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.c
index de0985ea..d50848be 100644
--- a/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.c
+++ b/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.c
@@ -648,7 +648,7 @@ skip_insignificant_space (const char *resource, int *pos, int resource_length)
 	return FALSE;
 }
 
-static char*
+char*
 sniff_feed_or_html (SoupContentSniffer *sniffer, GBytes *buffer)
 {
 	gsize resource_length;
diff --git a/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.h b/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.h
index 7f23b65d..e0e23052 100644
--- a/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.h
+++ b/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.h
@@ -23,5 +23,8 @@ char               *soup_content_sniffer_sniff (SoupContentSniffer  *sniffer,
                                                 GBytes              *buffer,
                                                 GHashTable         **params);
 
+SOUP_AVAILABLE_IN_ALL
+char *sniff_feed_or_html(SoupContentSniffer *sniffer, GBytes *buffer);
+
 G_END_DECLS
 
```

### meson compile
```bash
$ meson setup build \
    -Ddefault_library=static -Dfuzzing=enabled \
    --reconfigure

$ meson compile -C build
```

## File `fuzzing/fuzz_content_sniffer.c`

```c
/* fuzzing/fuzz_content_sniffer.c */

#include "fuzz.h"

#define kMinInputLength 8
#define kMaxInputLength 1024

int
LLVMFuzzerTestOneInput(const unsigned char *data, size_t size)
{
    char                *content_type;
    GBytes              *bytes;
    SoupContentSniffer  *sniffer;

    if (size < kMinInputLength || size > kMaxInputLength)
        return 0;

    fuzz_set_logging_func();

    bytes = g_bytes_new(data, size);
    sniffer = soup_content_sniffer_new();

    content_type = sniff_feed_or_html(sniffer, bytes);

    g_bytes_unref(bytes);
    g_object_unref(sniffer);
    g_free(content_type);

    return 0;
}
```

## Reproduce crash

- Heap buffer overflow in `soup-content-sniffer.c:sniff_feed_or_html()`

```c
$ ./fuzz_content_sniffer crash-sniff_feed_or_html.bin
```

## Patch to fix

- `soup-content-sniffer.c:sniff_feed_or_html()` 

```patch
diff --git a/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.c b/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.c
index de0985ea..80563fd5 100644
--- a/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.c
+++ b/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.c
@@ -704,7 +704,7 @@ sniff_feed_or_html (SoupContentSniffer *sniffer, GBytes *buffer)
                do {
                        pos++;
 
-                       if (pos > resource_length)
+                       if (pos >= resource_length)
                                goto text_html;
                } while (resource[pos] != '>');
```

- `soup-content-sniffer.c:skip_insignificant_space()`

Note: Actually, there are two bugs, but I am considering both of them as one.

```patch
diff --git a/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.c b/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.c
index de0985ea..d8b3c29c 100644
--- a/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.c
+++ b/libsoup/content-sniffer/soup-content-sniffer.c
@@ -635,13 +635,16 @@ sniff_text_or_binary (SoupContentSniffer *sniffer, GBytes *buffer)
 static gboolean
 skip_insignificant_space (const char *resource, int *pos, int resource_length)
 {
+       if (*pos >= resource_length)
+               return TRUE;
+
        while ((resource[*pos] == '\x09') ||
               (resource[*pos] == '\x20') ||
               (resource[*pos] == '\x0A') ||
               (resource[*pos] == '\x0D')) {
                *pos = *pos + 1;
 
-               if (*pos > resource_length)
+               if (*pos >= resource_length)
                        return TRUE;
        }
 
```

> I would guess Medium possible reward since the likely impact is denial of service.

No, it would be High. It's a network; if this were a file format, then it would be Medium.

Also, it would be Medium if this was a memory leak (not in an infinite loop).

target_title: Follow up on `New Security Issue (#146)`

note.body:
# Report-2

Heap buffer overflow in `soup-content-sniffer.c:sniff_unknown()`

## Download

```bash
$ git clone https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libsoup.git
```

## Export flags

```bash
$ export CC=clang
$ export CXX=clang++
$ export CFLAGS="-g -O0 -DFUZZING_BUILD_MODE_UNSAFE_FOR_PRODUCTION -fsanitize=address -fsanitize=fuzzer-no-link"
$ export CXXFLAGS="-g -O0 -DFUZZING_BUILD_MODE_UNSAFE_FOR_PRODUCTION -fsanitize=address -fsanitize=fuzzer-no-link"
$ export LIB_FUZZING_ENGINE="-fsanitize=fuzzer"
```

## Compile

```bash
$ meson setup build \
    -Ddefault_library=static -Dfuzzing=enabled \
    --reconfigure

$ meson compile -C build
```

## File `fuzzing/fuzz_content_sniffer.c`

```c
/* fuzzing/fuzz_content_sniffer.c */

#include "fuzz.h"

#define kMinInputLength 8
#define kMaxInputLength 1024

int
LLVMFuzzerTestOneInput(const unsigned char *data, size_t size)
{
    char                *content_type;
    GBytes              *bytes;
    SoupMessage         *msg;
    SoupContentSniffer  *sniffer;

    if (size < kMinInputLength || size > kMaxInputLength)
        return 0;

    fuzz_set_logging_func();

    bytes = g_bytes_new(data, size);
    sniffer = soup_content_sniffer_new();
    msg = soup_message_new(SOUP_METHOD_GET, "https://example.org");

    content_type = soup_content_sniffer_sniff(sniffer, msg, bytes, NULL);

    g_bytes_unref(bytes);
    g_object_unref(sniffer);
    g_object_unref(msg);
    g_free(content_type);

    return 0;
}
```

target_title: Follow up on `New Security Issue (#146)`

note.body:
Original reporter: [Arjun](mailto:pkillarjun@protonmail.com)

Area: Platform component (libraries, tools)

## Message

# Report

Null pointer dereference in `soup-uri-utils.c:soup_uri_decode_data_uri()`

## Download

```bash
$ git clone https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libsoup.git
```

## Export flags

```bash
$ export CC=clang
$ export CXX=clang++
$ export CFLAGS="-g -O1 -DFUZZING_BUILD_MODE_UNSAFE_FOR_PRODUCTION -fsanitize=address -fsanitize=fuzzer-no-link"
$ export CXXFLAGS="-g -O1 -DFUZZING_BUILD_MODE_UNSAFE_FOR_PRODUCTION -fsanitize=address -fsanitize=fuzzer-no-link"
$ export LIB_FUZZING_ENGINE="-fsanitize=fuzzer"
```

## Compile

```bash
$ meson setup build
    -Ddefault_library=static -Dfuzzing=enabled
    --reconfigure

$ meson compile -C build
```

## File `fuzzing/fuzz_decode_data_uri.c`

```c
/* fuzzing/fuzz_decode_data_uri.c */

#include
#include "fuzz.h"

#define kMinInputLength 8
#define kMaxInputLength 128

int
LLVMFuzzerTestOneInput(const uint8_t *data, size_t size)
{
    char    *data_in;
    GBytes  *bytes;

    if (size  kMaxInputLength)
        return 0;

    fuzz_set_logging_func();

    /* Add NUL byte */
    data_in = calloc(size + 1, sizeof(char));
    if (data_in == NULL)
        return 0;

    memcpy(data_in, data, size);

    bytes = soup_uri_decode_data_uri(data_in, NULL);

    g_clear_pointer(&bytes, g_bytes_unref);
    g_free(data_in);

    return 0;
}
```

## Reproduce crash

```c

./fuzz_decode_data_uri: Running 1 inputs 1 time(s) each.
Running: crash-fuzz_decode_data_uri.bin
AddressSanitizer:DEADLYSIGNAL
=================================================================
==77646==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: SEGV on unknown address 0x000000000005 (pc 0x7f3d7eb22303 bp 0x7ffcd4730290 sp 0x7ffcd472fa48 T0)
==77646==The signal is caused by a READ memory access.
==77646==Hint: address points to the zero page.
    #0 0x7f3d7eb22303 in __strchr_avx2 (/lib64/libc.so.6+0x149303) (BuildId: 948d229348b56bdcf4e0a96d5ccd8fb175f617f0)
    #1 0x000000456908 in strchr (/home/magic/libsoup/build/fuzzing/fuzz_decode_data_uri+0x456908) (BuildId: b7f7d07ef0032cbd95aa7eefd781b9b7dbd09661)
    #2 0x00000051e04c in soup_uri_decode_data_uri /home/magic/libsoup/build/../libsoup/soup-uri-utils.c:308:17
    #3 0x00000051c902 in LLVMFuzzerTestOneInput /home/magic/libsoup/build/../fuzzing/fuzz_decode_data_uri.c:25:13
    #4 0x0000004207da in fuzzer::Fuzzer::ExecuteCallback(unsigned char const*, unsigned long) (/home/magic/libsoup/build/fuzzing/fuzz_decode_data_uri+0x4207da) (BuildId: b7f7d07ef0032cbd95aa7eefd781b9b7dbd09661)
    #5 0x000000407cf7 in fuzzer::RunOneTest(fuzzer::Fuzzer*, char const*, unsigned long) (/home/magic/libsoup/build/fuzzing/fuzz_decode_data_uri+0x407cf7) (BuildId: b7f7d07ef0032cbd95aa7eefd781b9b7dbd09661)
    #6 0x00000040e336 in fuzzer::FuzzerDriver(int*, char***, int (*)(unsigned char const*, unsigned long)) (/home/magic/libsoup/build/fuzzing/fuzz_decode_data_uri+0x40e336) (BuildId: b7f7d07ef0032cbd95aa7eefd781b9b7dbd09661)
    #7 0x00000043b306 in main (/home/magic/libsoup/build/fuzzing/fuzz_decode_data_uri+0x43b306) (BuildId: b7f7d07ef0032cbd95aa7eefd781b9b7dbd09661)

    #9 0x7f3d7e9dc30a in __libc_start_main@GLIBC_2.2.5 (/lib64/libc.so.6+0x330a) (BuildId: 948d229348b56bdcf4e0a96d5ccd8fb175f617f0)
```

## Patch to fix

```patch
diff --git a/libsoup/soup-uri-utils.c b/libsoup/soup-uri-utils.c
index 4e76b74d..c1650c0b 100644
--- a/libsoup/soup-uri-utils.c
+++ b/libsoup/soup-uri-utils.c
@@ -303,6 +303,8 @@ soup_uri_decode_data_uri (const char *uri,

         uri_string = g_uri_to_string (soup_uri);
         g_uri_unref (soup_uri);
+        if (uri_string == NULL)
+                return NULL;

         start = uri_string + 5;
         comma = strchr (start, ',');
```

### Note

Whose idea was it to use YesWeHack? Fire that person.

The security@gnome.org alias was decommissioned four years ago due to excessive spam. Hopefully you should have received a bounce message? It certainly won't reach GNOME security team anymore. Maybe our sysadmins will read it eventually?

We did receive your issue report and have moved it to https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libsoup/-/issues/400. However, GitLab does not allow any way to give you permission to view that issue. You can only interact with it using Support Bot via email. :disappointed: 

Simple solution: I have set this issue report to confidential. Now we can continue here. I will paste your entire original report in the next comment.

target_title: Read port as `gint` instead of `glong` in `soup_uri_copy`

note.body: It works for the first few arguments, because they are passed in registers, and `int` is implicitly extended. But on some architectures (aarch64) arguments passed through the stack (9th and later) will be clobbered: https://trofi.github.io/posts/308-a-breakage-example-in-c-variadic-function.html

target_title: Read port as `gint` instead of `glong` in `soup_uri_copy`

note.body:
The existing cases are all broken on 64-bit Linux then, right? You surely cannot pass an int to a varargs function that expects long without it clobbering the arguments. The types are not the same size.

At minimum, we need to document what the expected types are.

CC: @mcrha

target_title: Read port as `gint` instead of `glong` in `soup_uri_copy`

note.body:
I've searched on Github and in the sources of Alpine packages that depend on `libsoup3`, and found only these uses of `soup_uri_copy` with `SOUP_URI_PORT`:
- https://github.com/GNOME/evolution-data-server/blob/7131f4ccf080d8fcdfc750f0f12efab089baab30/src/libedataserver/e-source-webdav.c#L258
- https://github.com/GNOME/evolution-data-server/blob/7131f4ccf080d8fcdfc750f0f12efab089baab30/src/libedataserver/e-data-server-util.c#L3047
- https://github.com/GNOME/evolution-data-server/blob/7131f4ccf080d8fcdfc750f0f12efab089baab30/src/libedataserver/e-data-server-util.c#L3079

And all of them assume that the port is `int`, so I doubt that `glong` has ever been used (and the documentation does not mention that `glong` is needed).

target_title: Read port as `gint` instead of `glong` in `soup_uri_copy`

note.body:
Maybe we should just deprecate this function.

Your change looks correct to me, but now any existing code that uses glong will result in memory corruption. So I think there's no winning here....

target_title: keepalive connection closed when after HTTP/1.1 HEAD request, or 204 / 304 response

note.body:
I tried adding a `soup_message_headers_set_encoding` call in `parse_headers`.  
But it removes the `Content-Length` header, which can be sent in the response for `HEAD` (telling the size of the body which would be returned by a `GET`), so could be useful for the client.

Should we duplicate the logic in `soup_message_is_keepalive`, to check the method/status first ?

Also, when trying to write a test for this, I see that the server closes the connection after a 204 (but not after HEAD or 304).
